, Brazil. It is principally an industrial city and many of its 500,000 inhabitants are of German descent.

Joinville, in its first year known as Colônia Dona Francisca, was founded in 1851 by German, Swiss and Norwegian immigrants. Even though it is considered a German-Brazilian city, its name is French (Joinville was named after François d'Orléans, prince of Joinville, son of King Louis-Philippe of France, who married Princess Francisca of Brazil, in 1843). 

The land where Joinville is located was part of the French and Brazilian Royal Family wedding gift, even though the Prince of Joinville and his Brazilian bride had never been to the land. However, a Royal Palace was built in their honor around 1870. In 1851, the French prince, after a financial crisis, sold almost all his lands in Southern Brazil to the German Senator Mathias Schröder.
Senator Schröder was a member of the Colonization Society of Hamburg, which attracted immigrants to be sent to Brazil and thereby establish commercial ties between Germany and the German communities in Brazil. In 1851, the first 118 German and Swiss immigrants arrived, followed by 74 Norwegian immigrants. From 1850 to 1888, Joinville received 17,000 German immigrants, most of them Lutherans, poor peasants coming to occupy this part of Brazil. Later waves of immigration brought large numbers of Italian families to the area as well.
Numerous cities around Brazil have flights to and from Joinville Airport, with the most regular (multiple daily flights) being

(Guarulhos Airport). 


Getting from Joinville airport to the city center, visitors have two options:

value: (recommended): The drive takes on average about 25 minutes and the fare is between 33 and 35 BRL (20-22 USD) in 2011

(recommended for locals only): There are no direct buses from the airport to the city center or the bus terminal (rodoviária). It is necessary to take a bus to Iririú and change there to a bus towards center.

Alternatively, it is possible to get to Joinville from almost any town or city in
by bus (Catarinense, the state's largest bus company, offers the greatest range). Outside Santa Catarina, several places offer bus services to Joinville, including
is the main highway through town, connecting from
to the north. If coming from the west via
, which intersects with BR-101 a few kilometers south of town, or
, which hits BR-101 at the north end of town. The main entrance to town is considered to be the exit at
, which leads east to the downtown district.

It is easiest to get around Centro (downtown) by foot, as everything is close together. Should you wish to venture out into the suburbs, Joinville has a reliable bus network which is used heavily by locals. Tickets can be purchased from any one of the numerous bus terminals around the city, or on the buses themselves. Be warned, however: both buses painted completely blue and those with a blue stripe on each side are direct buses, they generally go from one bus station to another without stopping.

value: Rua das Palmeiras in front of the National Museum of Immigration and Colonization.

content=Well worth a visit if you're in the area. This is the only school run by the famous Bolshoi Ballet Company outside of Russia. Guided tours are in Portuguese (though if you're lucky the guide may be fluent enough in English to give you a run down), and should be booked in advance.
content=A part of the Atlantic Forest with walking trails and a lookout with views on Babitonga Bay.
content=Has various trails for walking or mountain biking, and a lookout point from which you can see the Aventureiro neighborhood.
content=What was the local train station from 1906 to 1996 has now been restored and reconfigured to hold a railroad museum, a sporting center, skate park, a playground, and other attractions.
content=Holds 15,000 bicycles, the oldest of which is an Italian "Volcite" from 1906. It is currently closed
directions=at the main entrance to the city
content=A leisure center with an exposition center, a small park, a shopping area, a lake with pedalboats, and a model car racetrack.
name=National Museum of Immigration and Colonization
alt=Museu Nacional de Imigração e Colonização
directions=in front of Rua das Palmeiras

content=This museum offers a glimpse of life as it was for Joinville's first European settlers . It includes a historic house set up as it would have been around 150 years ago, as well as well as a couple of sheds containing machinery which was used in past times.

content=A beautiful road with natural elements and German architecture and other German touches. Streets to either side lead to restaurants, residences, and fishing holes, and at the end of the road there is a typical German restaurant which offers dishes such as stuffed duck, and the Bonito River, good for a swim. There are also some trailheads from here.
content=A well known pedestrian-only street lined with palm trees which were brought from Rio de Janeiro in 1873. It is the quintessential postcard shot of the city.
content=Displays some fossils found in the region and tells of the northeast Santa Catarina's
, pre-historic shell-mounds created by an unknown people who lived along the coast between 6000BC and 0BC.
directions=on top of Morro da Boa Vista, the rainforest-covered hill next to Centro
content=This 250-meter tower is one of the city's main attractions. It offers an impressive panoramic view of the city and of Babitonga Bay.
content=A typical German immigrant house which shows how the Germans lived during the colonial period.
address=João de Souza Mello e Alvim Highway - Vila Cubatão
content=Joinville's only beach borders Babitonga Bay. It doesn't have a lot of sand, but is a safe place to swim, and there are a number of bars and restaurants along it.
directions=at the base of the lookout on Morro da Boa Vista
content=Joinville's zoo houses a modest collection of Brazilian animals and local flora.
A presentation by the Bolshoi Ballet Company during the 2006 Joinville Dance Festival.
price=Some event free, others R$12 to R$110 per event, depending on the event and the seat

content=Considered the biggest dance festival in the world, thousands of dancers from all over Brazil and beyond flock to the city, making it possibly the best time to visit the city. For the duration of the event, various public spaces throughout Centro become the setting of all kinds of dance performances, from hip hop to ballet. The festival cumulates with 'Champions Night', where the winners of all the categories perform in the Bolshoi Ballet Theater. It is sure to be a memorable night, though be warned: tickets sell fast.
name=Public Municipal Market Germano Kurt Freisler
alt=Mercado Público Municipal German Kurt Freisler
content=Some of the best shopping in the city, including many fashion outlets and other stores.

In addition to the standard array of Brazilian, Italian, and Middle Eastern food that can be found pretty much anywhere in Brazil, Joinville is an excellent place to enjoy traditional
cuisine, and restaurants of this type can be found throughout the city. Also look to pick up some

value: apple ''strudel''''' at one of the many confectioneries, and keep an eye out for locally produced
such as Joinvilândia. If you're having trouble deciding what to eat, take a stroll down

Rua Visconde de Taunay''', the city's biggest concentration of restaurants and bars.

value: content=One of the more famous German restaurants in town, revered for its typical German dishes and cold draft beer. You may even bump into celebrities eating here.

- It could be worth making the trip to this a fishing community on an island across from Joinville; it is around a 30 minute drive by car, or can be reached by ferry from Vigorelli Beach (
section above). São Francisco do Sul was one of the very first places in Brazil to be colonized by Europeans and the old area is full of brightly coloured Portuguese buildings.
